sentences.sentence: When Mr. Darcy gave Elizabeth the letter, she had no expectation at all about what it might contain.
But it is easy to imagine how eagerly she went through the letter, and what a mixture of emotion( 情绪 ) it caused her.
With a strong prejudice( 偏见 ) against everything he might say, she read what he wrote about what had happened at Netherfield.
His belief that her sister did not truly care for Mr. Bingley she knew to be false, and what he said next regarding his real objections to the match made her too angry to ever want to forgive him.
Nothing he had said could excuse what he had done.
But when she read what he said about Mr. Wickham, her feelings( 感受 ) were more painful and more difficult to define( 辨别 ).
She felt astonishment( 惊讶 ), dread( 担心 ), and even horror( 恐惧 ), and tried to find a way to disprove( 反驳 ) it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming( 大喊 ), “This must be false!
This cannot be! This must be the greatest falsehood( 谎言 )!”
And yet she could see that the affair, which she had been sure must prove Mr. Darcy’s conduct to be disgraceful( 羞愧的 ),
could be looked at in a light which would make him entirely blameless.
Mr. Darcy’s accusations( 责备 ) that Wickham was extravagant( 挥霍的 ) and immoral( 不道德的 ) exceedingly( 极其地 ) shocked her, especially as she could find no proof( 证据 ) of their injustice.
Of Wickham’s life before he met her, all she knew was what he had told her himself.
She had never really tried to find out about his actual character.
His handsome face, melodious( 好听的 ) voice, and agreeable manner had proved him at once to possess every virtue( 美德 ).
She tried to remember some example of his goodness, integrity( 正直 ), or generosity that might rescue him from the attacks of Mr. Darcy,
or at least make up for those casual( 偶尔的 ) errors that Mr. Darcy had described as many years of idleness( 闲散 ) and vice( 恶习 ).
But no such memory came to her.

She could see him instantly before her, in all his charm( 魅力 ), but other than the fact that his fellow soldiers and the people of Meryton all approved( 认同 ) of Wickham, she could remember nothing really good about him.
She remembered perfectly everything Wickham had said during their first evening at the Phillipses’ house.
Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory.
She now noticed how inappropriate( 不合适的 ) it was that he would tell such things to a stranger, and wondered why she had not realized this before.
How different all those events involving Wickham now appeared, looking back on them!
Remembering also how quickly he had suddenly taken an interest in Miss King,
she realized that this only proved further how willing he was to do anything that would improve his own position.
She felt absolutely( 非常 ) ashamed of herself.
She could not think of either Darcy nor Wickham without feeling that she had been blind, prejudiced( 心存偏见的 ), and foolish.
“How disgracefully( 羞愧地 ) I have acted!” she cried, “and to think that I once took pride in my good judgment!
Even if I had been in love, I could not have been more wretchedly( 可怜地 ) blind!
Till this moment, I never knew myself.”
She wandered alone for two hours, trying to accept, as much as she could, such a sudden and important change.
At last she returned to the Collinses’ house, and as she entered the house, she tried to appear as cheerful as usual.
On Saturday morning Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared,
and he took the opportunity of saying the formal( 正式 ) goodbyes( 再见 ) which he felt were absolutely( 很 ) necessary.
At last the carriage arrived and they were ready to depart( 离开 ).
“It seems like only a few days since we first arrived, and yet so much has happened!” said Maria,
“How much I shall have to tell on our return!” Elizabeth privately said to herself,
“And how much I shall have to conceal( 隐瞒 )!”
After a warm farewell( 告别 ) between the friends( 朋友 ), Elizabeth was walked to the carriage by Mr. Collins, and they began their journey.
Within four hours of leaving Mr. Collins’s house, they arrived at the Gardiners’, where they were to remain for several days.
Jane looked well, but Elizabeth had little opportunity to determine how she was really feeling, because her aunt had arranged many activities for them all to do together.
But she and Jane were soon going home together, and at Longbourn there would be enough time for Elizabeth to observe her more closely.
It was difficult for Elizabeth to wait even until they returned to Longbourn before she could tell her sister about Mr. Darcy’s proposal( 求婚 ).
It was almost too much of a temptation( 诱因 ) to think of how astonished( 惊讶的 ) Jane would be when she at last knew the truth.
Her only reason for hesitation( 犹豫 ) was that she had not yet decided exactly how much she would tell her sister,
out of fear that she might hurt her sister by mentioning something about Mr. Bingley.
They were very kindly welcomed when they returned home.
Mrs. Bennet was excited to see Jane’s beauty remained unchanged, and more than once during dinner, Mr. Bennet said voluntarily to Elizabeth:
“I am glad you have come back, Lizzy.”
The next morning, Elizabeth told Jane most of the details( 细节 ) of what happened between Mr. Darcy and herself,
with the exception of what had been said by Mr. Darcy about Jane and Bingley.
Miss Bennet was sorry that Mr. Darcy should have proposed( 求婚 ) in such an unfortunate manner, but more sorry for the unhappiness which her sister’s refusal must have given him.
“His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” she said, “but consider how much it must increase his disappointment!”
“You do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”
“Blame you! Oh, no.”
“But do you blame me for having spoken so warmly of Wickham?”
“No—I do not know that you were wrong in saying what you did.”
“But you will know it, when I tell you what happened the very next day.”
